                             BIBLIOGRAPHIC CITATION                            
                                                                               
                                                                               
          Publications based  on   ICPSR   data   collections   should         
          acknowledge   those  sources  by  means   of   bibliographic         
          citations.  To ensure  that  such  source  attributions  are         
          captured   for  social  science   bibliographic   utilities,         
          citations must appear  in  footnotes  or  in  the  reference         
          section of  publications.   The  bibliographic  citation for         
          this data collection is:                                             
                                                                               
                                                                               
                  U.S. Dept. of Justice, Bureau of Justice Statistics.         
                  NATIONAL  PROSECUTORS  SURVEY, 1992 [Computer file].         
                  Conducted by U.S. Dept. of Commerce, Bureau  of  the         
                  Census.  ICPSR  ed.  Ann Arbor, MI: Inter-university         
                  Consortium  for  Political   and   Social   Research         
                  [producer and distributor], 1994.                            
                                                                               
                                                                               
                REQUEST FOR INFORMATION ON USE OF ICPSR RESOURCES              
                                                                               
                                                                               
          To provide funding agencies with essential information about         
          use of archival resources and to facilitate the exchange  of         
          information about  ICPSR  participants' research activities,         
          users of  ICPSR  data  are  requested  to  send   to   ICPSR         
          bibliographic citations  for  each  completed  manuscript or         
          thesis abstract.  Please indicate in a  cover  letter  which         
          data were used.                                                      
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                 DATA DISCLAIMER                               
                                                                               
                                                                               
          The original collector of the data, ICPSR, and the  relevant         
          funding agency  bear  no  responsibility  for  uses  of this         
          collection or for interpretations or inferences  based  upon         
          such uses.

1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                        i                                      
                                                                               
                                  INTRODUCTION                                 
                                                                               
                                                                               
                           DATA COLLECTION DESCRIPTION                         
                                                                               
                                                                               
             The National Prosecutor Survey Program (NPSP) is a biennial       
        survey of chief prosecutors in State court systems. A "chief           
        prosecutor" is an official, usually locally-elected and typically      
        with the title of district attorney or county attorney, who is in      
        charge of a prosecutorial district made up of one or more              
        counties, and who conducts or supervises the prosecution of            
        felony cases in a State court system.                                  
                                                                               
             The second NPSP survey was conducted in the summer months of      
        1992 and yielded the data file, NATIONAL PROSECUTORS SURVEY,           
        1992, described in this codebook. The NPSP 1992 survey sample of       
        290 chief prosecutors were drawn from a total of nearly 2,400          
        across the country. The data collection instrument was a mailed        
        questionnaire. The survey's purpose was to obtain detailed             
        descriptive information on prosecutors' office, as well as             
        information on their policies and practices.                           
                                                                               
             The contents of the NPSP-1 questionnaire, used in the NPSP        
        survey of 1992, were based on the questions that had been              
        included on the NPSP survey of 1990. Other areas of current            
        concern, covered in 1992 but not 1990 include:                         
                                                                               
             -    staffing, turnover, and recruitment                          
             -    new kinds of felonies                                        
             -    problem cases                                                
             -    scientific evidence                                          
             -    computerization                                              
             -    staff training                                               
             -    drug testing                                                 
             -    personal risks associated with the role of prosecutors       
                                                                               
             Several of the NPSP-1 questions, which asked about staffing,      
        total budget and workload, required quantitative answers.              
        However, the questionnaire primarily relied on multiple choice         
        queries, with the inclusion of an "other (please specify)"             
        provision to find out what other categories applied in actual          
        practice. This codebook provides itemizations of the responses         
        to the "other (please specify)" queries.                               
                                                                               
             Respondents were instructed that the data supplied should         
        relate to a "reference year" running July 1, 1991 to June 30,          
        1992. If the respondent had data for some other recent one-year        
        time interval, the beginning and end points were to be stated.         
        Nearly all respondents were able to supply information relating        
        to the requested reference year.                                       
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                     ii                                        
                                                                               
                                                                               
             For 190 of the 290 respondents, their prosecutorial district      
        consisted entirely of one county. The other 100, however, had          
        districts comprised of two or more counties.  For most of the          
        survey questions, respondents were asked to provide data for the       
        entire prosecutorial district, even if it included more than one       
        county. The only exceptions were Questions 14 and 17. For              
        Question 14, which asked about felony and misdemeanor workload         
        statistics, and for Question 17, which asked about staffing,           
        turnover and recruitment, respondents were asked to provide            
        statistics for the entire district and for the primary                 
        jurisdiction named on the front cover of the questionnaire.            
                                                                               
1                                                                              
                                   iii                                         
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                                                               
                       DATA COLLECTION PROCEDURES                              
                                                                               
                                                                               
             The survey was conducted by means of a mailed questionnaire       
        (NPSP-1) consisting of 43 questions which encompassed 437 items        
        of information. The questionnaires were mailed to the 290 chief        
        prosecutors by the Census Bureau in August 1992. Follow-up             
        continued until March 1992. Of the 290 prosecutors' offices in         
        the survey, 262 or 90 percent completed the questionnaire.             
                                                                               
                                                                               
                            SAMPLING INFORMATION                               
                                                                               
                                                                               
             The sample of 290 chief prosecutors in this survey were           
        chosen because they had offices in the 300 counties whose courts       
        had participated in the nationally representative survey of 1990       
        felony sentencing for the National Judicial Reporting Program          
        (NJRP). Therefore, the prosecutors with offices in those               
        counties were equivalent to a nationally representative sample of      
        chief prosecutors. The NJRP survey design ensures that the NPSP        
        survey covers prosecutorial districts of all sizes. Reliance on        
        NJRP counties also meant that felony sentencing data for 1990          
        could be added to the NPSP data file providing summary                 
        information on felony conviction offenses, sentences received,         
        method of conviction, and case processing time.                        
                                                                               
             It should be noted that the same 290 chief prosecutors had        
        been surveyed in 1990, the first year of the biennial NPSP             
        survey.                                                                
                                                                               
             One third of the prosecutorial districts in the NPSP sample,      
        and an estimated 20 percent nationwide, encompass more than one        
        county. As a consequence, 262 out of the 290 chief prosecutors         
        responded to the NPSP-1 questionnaire, but the data file,              
        NATIONAL PROSECUTORS SURVEY, 1992, has 271 individual county           
        records. Thus the number of records is greater by 9 than the           
        number of respondents. These 9 records represent responses from        
        the 9 chief prosecutors in the sample who had more than one NJRP       
        county. From a statistical standpoint, these 9 records can be          
        regarded as duplicates. Consequently, the prosecutor sampling          
        weight (NATWT) has been set to zero in these 9 records that are        
        regarded as duplicates. Hence any tabulations or analyses using        
        the prosecutor weight will not include those 9 records.                
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                   iv                                          
                                                                               
                                                                               
                           WEIGHTING INFORMATION                               
                                                                               
                                                                               
             Ideally, statistics computed using sample survey responses        
        have an "analysis weight" for conversion of the sample results to      
        statistics applicable to the entire population - in the NPSP           
        context, the entire population of felony prosecutors in State          
        courts. The analysis weight of a sample case is the inverse of         
        its probability of selection. For example, if a sample unit was        
        chosen as the result of a take one of every ten units procedure,       
        its probability is 0.1 and its weight is 10, i.e., it stands for       
        itself and nine other similar units that were not chosen.              
                                                                               
             In the NPSP survey, the probability of a chief prosecutor         
        being selected was the probability of inclusion in the NJRP            
        survey. The analysis weight which was applied to the data              
        provided by each sampled office was based on the inverse of the        
        probability of selection for NJRP. Chief prosecutors who had           
        felony responsibilities for more than one county had a                 
        probability of inclusion in NPSP equal to the probability of one       
        or more of the counties having been chosen for NJRP. These chief       
        prosecutors had more than one chance of being in the sample.           
                                                                               
             Some statistical adjustment had to be made for the 28 out of      
        290 chief prosecutors who did not respond to the 1992 survey           
        request. The adjustment method used was to recompute the               
        analysis weight based on response rates. To illustrate this            
        method, suppose hypothetically that 10 percent of the chief            
        prosecutors in a particular stratum were sampled, but only 8           
        percent responded. Then each respondent office had to represent        
        itself and eleven others, rather than itself and nine others as        
        originally planned. Hence, the sampling weight for those               
        respondents would have to be 12.5 (1/0.08) rather than 10              
        (1/0.10).                                                              
                                                                               
             The data file contains one analysis weight, NATWT. NATWT          
        has been set to zero in the case of county records that are            
        duplicates, as explained above.                                        
                                                                               
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                        v                                      
                                                                               
                                 FILE STRUCTURE                                
                                                                               
                                                                               
         The NATIONAL PROSECUTORS SURVEY, 1992 data file is available          
         from the ICPSR in single record per case format and has a             
         logical record length (LRECL) of 670. There are 448 variables         
         for the 271 cases.                                                    
                                                                               
         A raw character data file, a machine-readable codebook-listed-        
         to-tape, and SPSS and SAS control statements have been prepared       
         for this collection. For the data set, five SPSS control              
         statements--data list, variable labels, value labels, missing         
         value, and missing value recode statements--are contained in one      
         file. The five SAS control statements--proc format, input, label,     
         format and missing value recode statements--are contained in          
         another file.                                                         
                                                                               
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                       vi                                      
                                                                               
                                                                               
                              CODEBOOK INFORMATION                             
                                                                               
                                                                               
         Below is an example of information appearing in the                   
         machine-readable codebook for a typical variable. The                 
         numbers in brackets do not appear in the actual codebook but          
         are references to the descriptions which follow this example.         
                                                                               
     .......................................................................   
                                                                               
     [1] VAR 140         [2] 13B.1 BY ADULT OFFENDER              [3] NUMERIC  
     [4] WIDTH 1               [5] COLUMN 164                   [6] IMP DEC 0  
                              [7] MISSING 8, 9                                 
                                                                               
                                                                               
         [8] Q13b.1.  Who were these assaults committed by?                    
                                                                               
         Mark (X) all that apply                                               
                                                                               
         Adult offender                                                        
         ----------------------------------------------                        
                                                                               
         [9] Actual number is coded                                            
                                                                               
            [10] [11]                                                          
              1. Yes                                                           
              2. No                                                            
              8. Not applicable                                                
              9. Unknown                                                       
                                                                               
         ............................................................          
                                                                               
                                                                               
          [1]  Indicates the variable number assigned to each variable         
               in the data collection.                                         
                                                                               
          [2]  Indicates the abbreviated variable name (up to 24               
               characters) used to identify the variable for the user.         
               An expanded version of the variable name can be found in        
               the variable description list.                                  
                                                                               
          [3]  Indicates the variable type.  NUMERIC variables contain         
               numbers only, including numbers in E-notation, a decimal        
               point or minus sign. ALPHANUMERIC variables can be any          
               sequence of characters, including letters, numbers and          
               special characters: underscores (_), pound signs (#),           
               and ampersands (&).                                             
                                                                               
          [4]  Indicates the number of columns the variable occupies.          
                                                                               
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                                                               
                                      vii                                      
                                                                               
          [5]  Indicates the starting column in which the variable is          
               located. In this example, the variable named "13B.1 BY          
               ADULT OFFENDER" is 1 column wide and located in                 
               column 164 within the record.                                   
                                                                               
          [6]  The implied decimal specification for the variable              
               is denoted by the message "IMP DEC 0," where 0 is               
               the number of decimal places implied in the variable.           
                                                                               
          [7]  Indicates the code values of missing data. In this              
               example, code values of 8 and 9 are missing data                
               (MISSING 8, 9). Alternative statements for other                
               variables are "MISSING 998 OR GE 999," or "MISSING              
               NONE". Some analysis software packages require that             
               certain types of data which the user desires to be              
               excluded from analysis be designated as "MISSING",              
               e.g., inappropriate, unascertained, unascertainable,            
               or ambiguous data categories. Although these codes are          
               defined as missing data categories, this does not mean          
               that the user should not or cannot use them in a                
               substantive role if so desired.                                 
                                                                               
          [8]  This is the full text (question) supplied by the                
               investigator to describe the variable. The question             
               text and the numbers and letters that may appear at             
               the beginning reflect the original wording of the               
               questionnaire item.                                             
                                                                               
          [9]  Indicates an additional comment or explanation                  
               appended to the variable description. "Actual number is         
               coded" appears in the codebook to indicate that the             
               variable has been declared continuous.                          
                                                                               
         [10]  Indicates the code values occurring in the data for             
               this variable.                                                  
                                                                               
         [11]  Indicates the textual definitions of the codes.                 
               Abbreviations commonly used in the code definitions             
               are "DK" (Do Not Know), "NA" (Not Ascertained), and             
               "INAP" (Inappropriate).                                         
                                                                               
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                      viii                                     
                                                                               
                                                                               
                          ICPSR PROCESSING INFORMATION                         
                                                                               
                                                                               
         The data collection was processed according to the  standard          
         ICPSR processing procedures. The data were checked for                
         illegal or inconsistent code values which, when found, were           
         recoded to missing data values. No consistency checks were            
         performed. Statements bracketed in "[ ]" signs in the body            
         of the codebook were added by the processors for                      
         explanatory purposes.                                                 
1                                                                              
                                                                               
                                       ix

    V437* Number of felony defendants convicted in State court during          
          1990 in county where prosecutors' office is located                  
    V438* Percent of convicted felons in county whose most serious             
          conviction offense was murder, rape, robbery or                      
          aggravated assault                                                   
    V439* Percent of convicted felon in county whose most serious              
          conviction offense was fraud, larceny or burglary                    
    V440* Percent of convicted felons in county whose most serious             
          conviction offense was drug trafficking or felony drug possession    
    V441* Percent of convicted felons in county who received                   
          a prison sentence                                                    
    V442* Percent of convicted felons in county who received a jail - not      
          prison - sentence                                                    
    V443* Percent of convicted felons in county who received a sentence        
          of probation and no incarceration term                               
    V444* Percent of convicted felons in county who were convicted by          
          jury trial                                                           
    V445* Percent of convicted felons in county who were convicted based       
          on a guilty plea                                                     
    V446* Mean number of felony conviction charges per convicted felony        
          defendant in county                                                  
    V447* Mean number of days from arrest to conviction per convicted          
          felony defendant in county                                           
    V448  Prosecutor analysis weight                                           
                                                                               
    *V437-V447: Data are taken from the 1990 National Judicial Reporting       
     Program (NJRP).

         Stratum                                                               
         -------                                                               
                                                                               
              1.  Stratum 1 (certainty stratum): 19 counties with most         
                  convictions, plus 12 whose participation was prearranged.    
              2.  Stratum 2 (noncertainty stratum): 44 most populous counties  
                  not in stratum 1                                             
              3.  Stratum 3 (certainty stratum): 2,000+ convictions per county 
              4.  Stratum 4 (noncertainty stratum): 950-1,999 convictions per  
                  county                                                       
              5.  Stratum 5 (noncertainty stratum): 450-949 convictions per    
                  county                                                       
              6.  Stratum 6 (noncertainty stratum): 210-449 convictions per    
                  county                                                       
              7.  Stratum 7 (noncertainty stratum): 70-209 convictions per     
                  county

         SEE NOTE 16 IN APPENDIX                                               
         *******************************************************************   
                                                                               
         WORKLOAD STATISTICS                                                   
         Answers should refer only to the reference year.                      
                                                                               
         NOTE - Use the following definitions to complete [VAR].               
                                                                               
         Case - A case refers to a defendant. A defendant with                 
         multiple charges should be counted as one case. If you are            
         unable to provide defendant based answers - Specify in the            
         "NOTES" section on page 10, the method used to provide                
         counts for [VARS 144-153].                                            
                                                                               
         Closed case - Any case with a judgment of conviction,                 
         acquittal, or dismissial with prejudice, entered by the               
         court.                                                                
                                                                               
         Felony case - The definition of felony may vary by State.             
         (See terminology on page 2.) Include as a felony case, any            
         defendant who had at least one felony filing charge.                  
                                                                               
         Misdemeanor case - Any defendant who had only misdemeanor             
         filing charges.                                                       
                                                                               
         *******************************************************************   
                                                                               
     .......................................................................

                       ***Note 2***                                            
                                                                               
                                                                               
         STATE ID                                                              
         --------                                                              
                                                                               
         Identifies the State the prosecutor is in,                            
         States are listed alphabetically:                                     
                                                                               
         AL.......Alabama                  MT......Montana                     
         AK.......Alaska                   NE......Nebraska                    
         AZ.......Arizona                  NV......Nevada                      
         AR.......Arkansas                 NH......New Hampshire               
         CA.......California               NJ......New Jersey                  
         CO.......Colorado                 NM......New Mexico                  
         CT.......Connecticut              NY......New York                    
         DE.......Delaware                 NC......North Carolina              
         DC.......District of Columbia     ND......North Dakota                
         FL.......Florida                  OH......Ohio                        
         GA.......Georgia                  OK......Oklahoma                    
         HI.......Hawaii                   OR......Oregon                      
         ID.......Idaho                    PA......Pennsylvania                
         IL.......Illinois                 RI......Rhode Island                
         IN.......Indiana                  SC......South Carolina              
         IA.......Iowa                     SD......South Dakota                
         KS.......Kansas                   TN......Tennessee                   
         KY.......Kentucky                 TX......Texas                       
         LA.......Louisiana                UT......Utah                        
         ME.......Maine                    VT......Vermont                     
         MD.......Maryland                 VA......Virginia                    
         MA.......Massachusetts            WA......Washington                  
         MI.......Michigan                 WV......West Virginia               
         MN.......Minnesota                WI......Wisconsin                   
         MS.......Mississippi              WY......Wyoming                     
         MO.......Missouri                                                     
                                                                               
             99.  Data is blanked for confidentiality [public data set]

                       ITEMS 2d.8                                              
                                                                               
                                                                               
        V4: ICPSR SEQ        ENTRY                                             
        ID NUMBER                                                              
                                                                               
                                                                               
           4           Stalking                                                
                                                                               
          23           Pornography (child under age 14);                       
                       operating and endless chain scheme;                     
                       commercial bribery; arson at bookstore                  
                       or library; sexual exploitation of                      
                       patient by psychotherapist; resisting                   
                       peace officer; filing false report by                   
                       peace officer; looting during emergency;                
                       stalking; intercepting telephone                        
                       communication; importing Mediterranean                  
                       fruit fly; filing false claim for health                
                       carebenefit; fraud in obtaining
